Notice that $\mu \left( C ight)_j  = \left| {b_j ^\mu   \cap C} ight|$,  the number of the $i$ elements in $C$ which lie in the $j$th block of $\mu $.  Since elements of $\mathfrak{S}_\mu  $ preserve the blocks of $\mu $  (by definition), the composition $\mu \left( C ight)$ depends only on the orbit $O\left( {\mu ,C} ight)$, that is, $\mu \left( {ho C} ight) = \mu \left( C ight)$ for any $ho  \in \mathfrak{S}_\mu  $.  egin{lemma}\label{l10.1}
  Given $C \in C\left( {i,r} ight)$ and $ho  \in \mathfrak{S}_\mu  $ , let $ho C \in O\left( {\mu ,C} ight)$ be the image of $C$ under $ho $.  Then there exists a unique $ho _C  \in \mathfrak{S}_{\mu \left( C ight)} $ such that $ho  \cdot \phi _C  = \phi _{ho C}  \cdot ho _C $.  Conversely, given any $ho _C  \in \mathfrak{S}_{\mu \left( C ight)} $ and any $ho C \in O\left( {\mu ,C} ight)$, there exists a $ho ' \in \mathfrak{S}_\mu  $ such that $ho ' \cdot \phi _C  = \phi _{ho C}  \cdot ho _C $ and $ho 'C = ho C \in O\left( {\mu ,C} ight)$.
\end{lemma}

 egin{proof}

Let $C = \left\{ {1,2, \cdots ,i} \right\}$.  Then $\mu \left( C \right) = \lambda  \in \Lambda \left( {i,n} \right)$.  Let $S$ be the semistandard $\lambda $-tableau of type $\mu \left( C \right)$ where $S_{j,l}  = j\,,\,1 \leqslant l \leqslant \lambda _j \,,\,j = 1,2, \cdots ,k$.  There is only one standard $\lambda $-tableau of type $S$, namely $s = id$, the identity in $\mathfrak{S}_i $.  The orbit $O\left( {C,\mu } \right) = \left\{ C \right\}$, so $\# O\left( {C,\mu } \right) = 1$.  Also, $\phi _C :\bar i \to \bar r$ is the identity $\phi _C (j) = j\,,\,j = 1,2, \cdots ,i$.

     Next let  $D = \left\{ {\left\{ 1 \right\},\left\{ 2 \right\}, \cdots ,\left\{ {i - 1} \right\},\left\{ {i,i + 1,i + 2, \cdots ,r} \right\}} \right\}$.  Then $\mu \left( D \right) \in \Lambda \left( {i,n} \right)$ is given by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex47.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mu_{j}=\begin{cases}\lambda_{j}&\text{if $j\leqslant k$ }\\
1&\text{if $j=k+1,k+2,\cdots,k+(r-i)$ .}\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⩽</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mtext> .</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>

p^{k}&\text{if $j=m+1+l$ for $l=1,2,\cdots,q$ }\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo><</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mi>k</mi></msup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><msup><mi>p</mi><mi>k</mi></msup></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mtext> for </mtext><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><msup><mi>p</mi><mi>k</mi></msup></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></mrow><mtext> for </mtext><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>

There is only one standard $\lambda $-tableau of type $S$, namely $s = id$, the identity in $\mathfrak{S}_i $.  The orbit $O\left( {C,\mu } \right) = \left\{ C \right\}$, so $\# O\left( {C,\mu } \right) = 1$.  Also, $\phi _C :\bar i \to \bar r$ is the identity $\phi _C (j) = j\,,\,j = 1,2, \cdots ,i$.

     Now define $D \in D\left( {i,\tau _r ,r} \right)$ as follows:  $D$ contains $i - p^k $ single elements sets, one set $\left\{ l \right\}$ for each entry $l$ in rows $1$ through $a$ or rows $a + 2$ through $m + 1$ of $\mu $.  $D$ also contains $p^k $ sets with $q + 1$ entries:  for $1 \leqslant j \leqslant p^k $, the $j$ set $D_j $ contains the $j$th entry in row $a + 1$ and in each of the last $q$ rows of $\mu $.  As a composition of $i$, $\mu \left( D \right) = \mu \left( C \right)$, so we can take $T = S$ as a semistandard $\lambda $-tableau of type $\mu \left( D \right)$.  Then again there is only one standard $\lambda $-tableau of type $T$, namely $t = id$, the identity in $\mathfrak{S}_i $.  

     To define the orbit space $O\left( {D,\mu } \right)$, let $\mathfrak{S}_{\mu _{m + 1 + j} }  \subseteq \mathfrak{S}_\mu  $ be the group of permutations of  row $m + 1 + j$ of $\mu $.  For each $1 \leqslant j \leqslant q$, $\mathfrak{S}_{\mu _{m + 1 + j} }  \cong \mathfrak{S}_{p^k } $.  Let $G = \prod\limits_{j = 1}^q {\mathfrak{S}_{\mu _{m + 1 + j} } }  \subseteq \mathfrak{S}_\mu  $
 and for $\sigma  \in G$ let $D_\sigma   = D\sigma  \in D\left( {i,\tau _r ,r} \right)$.  Then $O\left( {D,\mu } \right) = \left\{ {D_\sigma  :\sigma  \in G} \right\}$.  Then $\# O\left( {D,\mu } \right) = o\left( G \right) = o\left( {\left( {\mathfrak{S}_{p^k } } \right)^q } \right) = \left( {p^k !} \right)^q $.  

      Notice that with our choice of an ordering of the subsets of $\bar r$, we get $\psi _{D_\sigma  } \left( j \right) = j\,,\,1 \leqslant j \leqslant i$, for any $\sigma  \in G$.  Then $\psi _{D_\sigma  }  \circ \phi _C  = id$, the identity mapping $\bar i \to \bar i$.  We have $ \,_S C_T^\lambda   = \,_s C_t^\lambda   = id \cdot r_\lambda   \cdot id = r_\lambda ,$ so

1&\text{if $m+2\leqslant j\leqslant\left({m+1}\right)+(r-i)$ .}\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo><</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>⩽</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>⩽</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>⩽</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>⩽</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mtext> .</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>

There is only one standard $\lambda $-tableau of type $S$, namely $s = id$, the identity in $\mathfrak{S}_i $.  The orbit $O\left( {C,\mu } \right) = \left\{ C \right\}$, so $\# O\left( {C,\mu } \right) = 1$.  Also, $\phi _C :\bar i \to \bar r$ is the identity $\phi _C (j) = j\,,\,j = 1,2, \cdots ,i$.

     Now define $D \in D\left( {i,\tau _r ,r} \right)$ as follows:  Let $x$ be the last element in row $\lambda _a $, that is, $x = \lambda _1  + \lambda _2  +  \cdots  + \lambda _a $.  $D$ contains $i - 1$ single elements sets, one set $\left\{ l \right\}$ for every $1 \leqslant l \leqslant i$ except $l = x$.  $D$ also contains one set with $r - i + 1$
 elements: $\left\{ {x,i + 1,i + 2, \cdots ,r} \right\}$.  As a composition of $i$, $\mu \left( D \right) = \mu \left( C \right)$, so we can take $T = S$ as a semistandard $\lambda $-tableau of type $\mu \left( D \right)$.  Then again there is only one standard $\lambda $
-tableau of type $T$, namely $t = id$, the identity in $\mathfrak{S}_i $.  

     We have $O\left( {D,\mu } \right) = \left\{ D \right\}$, $\# O\left( {D,\mu } \right) = 1$,  $\psi _D \left( j \right) =
     \begin{cases}
        j     &\text{if $1 \leqslant j \leqslant i$ }  \\
        x     &\text{if $j > i$ }
      \end{cases}.$  Then $\psi _D  \circ \phi _C  = id:\bar i \to \bar i$.  We have $\,_S C_T^\lambda   = \,_s C_t^\lambda   = id \cdot r_\lambda   \cdot id = r_\lambda  $, so $\,_S C_T^\lambda   \circ \psi _D  \circ \phi _C  \circ \,_S C_T^\lambda   = r_\lambda   \cdot id \cdot r_\lambda   = r_\lambda   \cdot r_\lambda   = o\left( {\mathfrak{S}_\lambda  } \right)\,r_\lambda  $.  Then writing $b = _{O\left( {C,\mu } \right),S} C_{O(D,\mu ),T}^\lambda   = \phi _C  \cdot \,_S C_T^\lambda   \cdot \psi _D ,$

\[
\begin{aligned}
 b \cdot b &= \phi _C  \cdot \,_S C_T^\lambda   \cdot \psi _D  \cdot \phi _C  \cdot \,_S C_T^\lambda   \cdot \psi _D \\
            &= \phi _C  \cdot o\left( {\mathfrak{S}_\lambda  } \right) \cdot r_\lambda   \cdot \psi _D  \\
             &= o\left( {\mathfrak{S}_\lambda  } \right) \cdot b .
\end{aligned}
\]
